subject: Languages
title: The Slavic Branch: From One to Many
description: A quick, practical guide to The Slavic Branch: From One to Many.

hook.text: Russian, Polish, Czech, and Bulgarian all descend from one ancestor spoken just 1,500 years ago.

buildup.text: Proto-Slavic split as Slavic peoples migrated across Eastern Europe in the 6th and 7th centuries.

discovery.text: The family has three branches: East (Russian, Ukrainian), West (Polish, Czech), and South (Serbian, Bulgarian).

twist.text: Czech and Slovak speakers can mostly understand each other. Russian and Polish speakers cannot.

climax.text: Despite political borders, Slavic languages form a dialect continuum across half of Europe.

punchline.text: What separated one language into a dozen was migration, mountains, and centuries of time.

quiz.question: What are the three branches of the Slavic language family?
